4.23.text:
>>Frank Doran: Last July, an early day motion
was tabled in House of Commons by Lyn Brown,

11.69.text:
the MP for West Ham. Lyn is the constituency
MP for the location of the Bryant and May

22.94.text:
factory. It has 108 signatures to date, which
makes it the 11th most signed EDM in this

28.60.text:
session of Parliament. I am pleased to say
I signed it, and I hope, Diana, you will confess

35.16.text:
to signing it as well. That makes it one of
the most popular EDMs of this session. On

41.84.text:
8 October last year, the Bryant and May matchwomen
strike was debated in the House of Commons,

46.93.text:
a debate again led by Lyn Brown. It was an
hour long debate, and the work of our speaker

54.95.text:
this evening, Dr Louise Raw, was highlighted
both in the EDM and in the debate. Lyn said

62.40.text:
in the debate, 'I am most grateful to Louise Raw,
whose outstanding work first published in

68.34.text:
2009 documents in fine detail the strike and
the events leading up to it. In Striking a

75.44.text:
Light: the Bryant & May Matchwomen and their
Place in History, she meticulously describes

80.11.text:
the life and times of the women who worked
at the match factory, and the events that

85.72.text:
led 1,400 women to walk out on strike in July
1888 and stay on strike for more than two

91.99.text:
weeks, until their demands were met.'
Louise, I know, was in the public gallery

96.32.text:
on that day to hear the debate, and she was
accompanied at that time by Ted Lewis descendant

101.96.text:
of one of the matchwomen. He is not able to
be here tonight, though we hoped he would

109.07.text:
be. We are delighted that Louise has agreed
to come and give this talk. Apparently, she

116.50.text:
became fascinated with the story of the matchwomen's
strike on the trade union history course.

122.42.text:
Frances might have been the tutor; I don't
know. She is denying it. She discovered the

126.73.text:
traditional version of events was crucially
flawed, and it became her mission to bring

130.75.text:
the incredible true story of courage and solidarity
to light. Louise tells me that no one was

136.40.text:
more surprised than she was when she ended
up doing a PhD, writing a book and organising

141.11.text:
a festival, and those Victorian East End girls
are to blame for it all. I am sure you are

146.44.text: all anxious to hear what Louise has to say.

152.50.text:
>>Dr Louise Raw: Thank you very much, Frank.
It is lovely to be here tonight and to see

159.29.text:
so many of you here as well, especially those
of you from Parliament, because was something

163.77.text:
happening today in Parliament? No, it would
have been on the news if it had been anything

168.44.text:
major?
Yes, I was here last October, and it was amazing

171.33.text:
to hear the Bryant and May matchwomen debated
in the House of Commons. It was not the first

176.29.text: time they had been discussed there. They made it to Parliament in the 1880s, which was the year

197.80.text:
of their famous strike, and that was incredible,
because to have women like this in Parliament

204.92.text:
was absolutely unheard of. Normally, the sort
of people you would expect to find in Parliament,

209.41.text:
like those of you here today, were very respectable
-- some of you; a few of you -- the great

216.05.text:
and good of the land. What you did not expect
to find or even hear discussed were working

222.70.text:
class women like these. They were generally
dismissed in their time, in the 1880s, as

229.30.text:
a 'rough set of girls', though, trust
me, you would not have said that to their

233.37.text:
faces, if you had any sense. I am afraid to
say they were not unknown to the local magistrates

239.43.text:
of the time, and it was said that, in the
East End, where they lived and worked, decent

244.83.text:
folk did not care to be outdoors when they
came off shift, because they did not want

248.54.text:
to be subjected to the language, I am afraid,
and the terrible behaviour of these matchwomen.

253.54.text:
As to how they dressed, well, we will get
on to that later, but I am afraid it shocked

259.15.text:
the Victorian middle classes: suffice to say,
far too much Victorian bling, and far too

265.58.text:
great an absence of maidenly modesty from
head and toe, and quite possibly all points

273.70.text:
How did they get here, or how did they get
over the road, in 1888, and why, as you may

278.73.text:
be asking yourself, am I banging on about
them today? There is a good reason. Our story

284.16.text:
begins in the East End of the 1880s. Think
Ripper Street, Charles Dickens and the adaptations

291.56.text:
you have seen on television. It was not a
good time to be in the East End. There were

297.98.text:
not many good times, to be fair, to be in
the East End up until quite recently, but

302.39.text:
this was a particularly bad one: only six
miles from where we are today, but an entire

307.71.text:
world away from posh London. East London,
at this point, was just starting to be called

314.71.text:
the East End. It was not called that before,
and there is a really good reason for that.

318.45.text: It has become a very particular kind of area.

321.70.text:
This is a typical scene of East End life.
This is a family of tailors. Although only

328.35.text:
the father would have been considered a military
tailor, they are all working; as you can see,

333.39.text:
the children are working, even the really
young kids. You can also see the state of

338.17.text:
the room, but you can see in the foreground
and to the side there are beds poking out.

344.28.text:
That is because that would have been their
home; that one room would have been their

347.97.text:
entire home. That is where they lived, worked,
cooked, ate and slept. That is a very typical

355.78.text:
scene in the East End at this time. It had
become a real home of what they called sweated

360.61.text:
labour, the worst, most exploitative kind
of labour.

365.21.text:
Because of its geographical position -- it
is surrounded on three sides by water -- it

369.46.text:
was a natural home for London's docks from
the 1700s onwards, and it became a centre

375.02.text:
for immigration and the cheapest, worst kind
of labour. The docks were the biggest employer

382.02.text:
of male casual labour. Now, when they say
'casual labour', they do not mean it was

387.92.text:
relaxed; they do not mean it was a bit of
a laugh. The only thing casual was the employer's

392.15.text:
attitude to their employees. You had no contract
of employment; you had no rights whatsoever.

397.17.text:
By the 1880s, with the coming of the steam
trains, the gentry, anyone who can afford

403.72.text:
to, moves out of the East End to the new suburbs
that have grown up because of the coming of

408.55.text:
the railways, so they travel back into the
East End to work, but they no longer live

413.72.text:
there. One writer said that, by the 1880s,
the flight of the gentry from the East End

419.65.text:
had become complete, and that what they left
behind was a monstrous hell of poverty.

426.53.text:
It was said, at points of the East End, around
this time, half of the children of the poor

432.71.text:
would not reach their fifth birthday -- quite
a damning indictment of the conditions. Living

438.57.text:
in one room like this, obviously, no matter
how hard you try, it is only going to be unhealthy;

442.58.text:
it is only going to be insanitary. Quite often,
people that were visiting the poor and writing

447.78.text:
about their lives would say that, as well
as inevitably the noise, having babies, having

452.83.text:
somebody perhaps ill in one corner, while
you were trying to work, you might have an

457.06.text:
ex member of the family with you; while you
were trying to save up for the funeral and

461.64.text:
the coffin, you might have granny in the corner
for a few days.

467.39.text:
This is the kind of image that you see a lot
of working class life in this period, a big

473.64.text:
contrast to the previous one. This is what
your posh Victorians thought the poor were

479.08.text:
getting up to. My friends from St Albans might
think this is a scene from our local pub on

483.99.text:
a Saturday night; it is not, but you can see
exactly what the Victorians think about the

488.27.text:
working classes here. They are having far
too much fun; they are wasting their money

491.68.text:
on booze when they should not be. I mean,
look at the state of them, really. Do they

495.77.text:
not look like the worst representations of
the race? This is exactly what people thought

500.61.text:
about the working classes in this age of eugenics.
This was a typical attack on working class

511.37.text:
life, and far away from the reality. East-Enders
were thought to be the worst of the worst,

516.90.text:
the poorest of the poor, and the term 'East-Ender'
develops right here and now as an insult.

523.40.text:
It was an insult to call somebody an 'East-Ender',
and it was said that if you had a shabby man

528.53.text:
from Battersea or one of the more respectable
parts of London, they might be alright, but

533.25.text:
if you had an East-Ender across your threshold,
look out. 'Reach for the bug powder',

536.70.text:
somebody said, 'and lock up the spoons':
disreputable types.

544.25.text:
The Bryant and May women are East-Enders;
they are working class women, and, worst of

549.85.text:
all, they are also factory girls. Now, this
image is factory girls attacking a constable.

556.93.text:
It is a cartoon from Punch of the day, and
you can see these women dressed to the nines,

562.50.text:
really rather glamorous, but out on the town
for a night, some drunk, having a disagreement

568.89.text:
with the local constabulary. Again, this is
how working class women of the time were seen.

575.02.text:
Another image has a caption, with the wife
in the middle saying, 'I say, George, this

583.52.text:
young person appears to know you.' It is
an awkward moment in a marriage. George has

591.04.text:
some explaining to do, but you can also say
that the girl is a flower seller as well,

596.63.text:
so she is also working. 'Working girl',
at this time, becomes a euphemism for prostitute,

601.74.text:
for the very reason that women are working
publicly in factories, not just doing what

607.41.text:
can be seen as feminine duties on farms or
in agriculture, and they are seen as a bit

612.44.text:
of a threat. East End women that had to indulge
in prostitution are obviously doing it to

618.71.text:
lure the poor, put-upon, respectable Georges
of the world, who only want to go home to

624.37.text:
their wives but are being lured into the dens
of iniquity of the East End by these women.

630.10.text:
The Victorians see this as a real threat,
but it is the women they see as the threat.

635.28.text:
It is the working classes that they see as
the threat. It is their fault they are poor;

639.46.text:
they are poor because they are not respectable
and, frankly, they do not live right; and

643.35.text:
they are bringing the rest of the race down
with them. I do not know if anyone mentioned

645.51.text:
the Daily Mail; I think I heard someone say
it. There is perhaps nothing new under the

651.06.text:
sun. Funnily enough, that paper was established
around that period, but I am sure that is

658.22.text:
Our matchwomen have all of that against them.
They are working class women; they are East

662.90.text:
Enders, and, also, I am afraid to tell you,
largely guilty of being Irish. It is just

668.10.text:
unforgivable, isn't it? You would not think
they would have the temerity to be Irish on

671.42.text:
top of all the rest of it. This is what Victorian
Londoners thought about the Irish community

676.63.text:
in the East End. This is the eminent Victorian
social chronicler Charles Booth, writing about

681.48.text:
an area of the East End that was known as
the 'Fenian barracks', and he said, 'Men

687.47.text:
here are not human. They are wild beasts.
This block sends more police to hospital than

693.37.text:
any in London. Arrest a man or a women, a
rescue is always organised. They will throw

700.81.text:
bricks, iron, anything they can get their
hands on. All are Irish Cockneys and not an

706.11.text:
Englishman nor a Scotchman will live amongst
them.' Quite right too. Here are our matchwomen:

713.75.text:
East Enders and Irish Cockneys, so, really,
they should have known their place, shouldn't

717.44.text:
they? They should have just done their jobs
and kept themselves quiet, but I am afraid

722.14.text: it did not quite go like that.

724.20.text:
In the summer of 1888, the streets of Bow
around the Bryant and May factory where they

730.16.text:
worked -- today, very posh housing; then,
the biggest employer of female casual labour

737.49.text:
in the East End by far -- were in an uproar.
It was nothing to do with Jack the Ripper

743.52.text:
yet, although it will be very soon after this
period. We are told that battalions of police

748.72.text:
are being bussed into the area at this point
as well. Police leave is pretty much cancelled

757.48.text:
throughout the country. What is going on that
is so appalling? The matchwomen have only

761.98.text:
gone and gone on strike. 1,400 of them have
laid down their tools and walked out of the

768.59.text:
factory, and immediately begun picketing at
the gates. Bryant and May had become so powerful

776.83.text:
at this time that they had driven wages down.
Wages were lower at this point than they had

783.30.text:
been 10 years previously, but Bryant and May
were doing incredibly well. Their products

787.40.text:
were ubiquitous. If you thought of matches,
you thought of Bryant and May, and their profits

792.24.text:
were incredible as well. The shareholders
were getting 20% dividends, which is not a

796.36.text: bad little return on your investment.

798.56.text:
However, Frank mentioned at the beginning
Annie Besant, a journalist who exposed conditions

804.34.text:
inside the factory, of whom more later, who
said that you could see the truth of the lower

813.27.text:
wages, the fact that wages had been lowered
in the last decade, if you looked at the youngest

818.77.text:
girls. These are some of the women who went
on strike in 1888. They were very young; some

824.83.text:
of these girls could have been 11 or 12; most
of them were teenagers. Annie Besant said

829.45.text:
that, when she came to interview them, you
could see, by looking at them, that the youngest

834.39.text:
girls, who would or should have been growing
physically when these lower wages came into

840.43.text:
being, were really frail. Working class women
of this period were not the most robust anyway,

847.74.text:
but, even for their class and age, they were
noticeably really tiny, frail and unhealthy

853.76.text: looking. They were, in fact, malnourished.

857.89.text:
What made matters worse at Bryant and May,
though, was that the employers also fined

862.50.text:
them rather generously from their wages. Actually,
it was illegal, but a little thing like that

866.78.text:
did not bother Bryant and May; they had friends
in very high places. One girl gave Annie Besant

873.37.text:
an example of the kind of fines. She said,
'Well, let me give an example. I was fined

879.69.text:
recently because one of the machines was cutting
our fingers, and so I altered it. I knew that

886.22.text:
I could alter it and it would still work,
but it would be safer.' Well, the foreman

891.78.text:
was furious when he found out, and he said
to her, 'Put it back how it was. The machine

898.04.text:
is worth more than you are -- never mind
your fingers.' It is a business cost analysis

903.40.text:
of the kind that perhaps we might even see
today. She said, 'A couple of weeks after

909.76.text:
that, one of my workmates had her fingers
severed completely by this same machine.'

915.54.text:
What happened? She was sacked, and there was
of course no compensation, no trade union,

920.17.text:
in those days, so she was just out of work:
you cannot make matches without the correct

924.39.text:
complement of fingers, so that was that for
her.

929.82.text:
The most popular type of match in this period
was called 'the Lucifer', appropriately

935.26.text:
enough. It required white phosphorus to make
it. There were alternative kinds of matches

940.93.text:
with a different, safer kind of phosphorus.
White phosphorus caused what the women knew

945.99.text:
as 'phossy jaw', which they dreaded. It
was a horrific industrial disease of matchmaking.

950.78.text:
Here is a poor chap, who was probably a match
dipper, and you can see he completely lost

957.16.text:
his jawbone through phosphorus necrosis. What
would happen was that the particles of phosphorus

963.38.text:
that were in the air would work their way
into your jawbone; you would probably have

968.39.text:
holes in your teeth in those days; you would
not be able to afford the dentist. They would

971.60.text:
work their way in; they would go straight
to the jawbone, which would start to rot and

976.01.text:
decay. I am sorry if you just had tea, by
the way; this is rather gory. Apparently,

980.15.text:
the odour of the abscesses that formed was
so unpleasant that even loved ones could not

986.81.text:
stand to be under the same roof as sufferers,
which leads to great tragedies, as factories

992.36.text:
inspectors will later find matchmakers, women
and men, living on the outskirts of towns

997.87.text:
and cities, almost like lepers, in the final
stages of this horrible disease.

1003.33.text:
When I was doing a talk at the Museum of London,
someone told me that his grandparents had

1006.99.text:
lived near the factory at this time, and they
had always told him when he was a boy, 'You

1012.78.text:
know you could see the matchwomen's routes
home from work every day because of the piles

1016.92.text:
of fluorescing vomit in the gutters', because
phosphorus also makes you, your clothes and

1023.61.text:
apparently also the contents of your stomach
fluoresce. It is actually banned now as a

1027.93.text:
weapon of war. That is how unpleasant it is;
you cannot use it to kill people -- absolutely

1031.22.text:
fine, though, to have the working classes
handling it to make matches in this period.

1037.69.text:
This is a typical jawbone of a phosphorus
victim, and you can see that all the teeth

1046.93.text:
have gone from one side completely, and the
jawbone has completely rotted away. It is

1051.22.text:
really just a hideous disease, and, understandably,
the women dreaded it.

1056.94.text:
What made matters particularly bad in this
one factory was that there was no separate

1061.93.text:
dining room, so you would bring in your bit
of stale bread from home that you would have

1066.52.text:
for your lunch and you would put it on your
workbench, so, by the time you came to eat

1071.50.text:
it, the phosphorus particles in the air have
filtered down and settled on it, so it has

1076.53.text:
a ready route into your mouth. I was saying
to Melanie beforehand that, when I did a talk

1082.84.text:
in a school -- they say 'never work with
children', don't they? -- I showed this

1087.09.text:
awful image, expecting the dear kiddies to
be quite struck and upset by it. One of the

1093.46.text:
boys said, 'Well, miss, you know you said
they were poor.' I said, 'Yes, they were

1096.55.text:
-- terribly low wages.' He said, 'Yeah,
but they must have got a lot of money from

1099.15.text: the tooth fairy, though.' Never, ever again.

1105.66.text:
When the women walked out on strike, people
blamed the journalist we have mentioned, Annie Besant.

1112.50.text:
She was a middle class journalist, a political
activist and a Fabian. Everyone assumed that,

1119.31.text:
because she had written about Bryant and May
in this hard hitting piece I have been quoting,

1123.12.text:
'White Slavery in London', she must have
organised the strike, because a bunch of working

1129.29.text:
class girls would not have been intelligent
enough to go on strike on their own; they

1134.12.text:
needed help; they needed to be shown the way;
they needed someone to tell them they were

1138.14.text:
being exploited; they probably had not noticed
at all. The interesting thing is that this

1144.89.text:
traditional story had really stayed that way
until into the 1890s, and that is pretty much

1152.92.text:
where I came in. I do not mean in 1888, before
you ask, although sometimes it feels like

1157.64.text:
I was there. I was definitely not an academic,
as Frank said; I was on a trade union labour

1162.75.text:
history course when I first got interested
in this story. Having been involved in strikes,

1168.59.text:
I was really curious about the way this story
was told, and could not quite work it out.

1173.50.text:
I thought it asked as many questions as it
answered.

1180.92.text:
What really puzzled me was how a woman like
Besant, at a time of really brutal class divides,

1186.35.text:
had supposedly gone down to a factory, interviewed
some of the women and then caused the strike,

1192.57.text:
so presumably said, 'I say, girls, I'm
in the Fabian Society and we've had a vote,

1197.24.text:
and we've decided that you're going out
on strike a week Wednesday. Is that alright?'

1202.44.text:
and they have all said, 'Ooh, God bless
you, ma'am. Yes, absolutely. We'll be

1203.88.text:
there.' Knowing East End women, I cannot
imagine that the answer would have been 'whatever

1207.41.text:
you say, ma'am', given that they would
have been giving up their wages, giving up

1210.70.text:
their jobs; they knew they could be sacked
just like that by Bryant and May. It did not

1215.39.text:
make sense to me, and I thought, 'Well,
let's work out how this woman did it. Perhaps

1219.52.text:
I can pick up some tips.' I started looking
at all the accounts from the period, thinking

1225.51.text:
they must describe her tactics; they must
say, 'Annie Besant had a meeting and she

1228.94.text:
said this, and she said, "We'll have a
strike fund", and she persuaded the women

1233.09.text:
to go out on strike', but there was nothing;
in all the contemporary histories, it just

1237.60.text:
said, 'Annie Besant wrote an article. Bang
-- the matchwomen went out on strike. Annie Besant

1244.04.text:
Well, I kept reading and reading and studying
in a really quite disorganised way, to be

1248.33.text:
honest; not in a very academic way at all.
People have said to me since, 'It is very

1252.31.text:
interesting, your methodology that you use.'
I just sort of say, 'Yeah, definitely.'

1255.77.text:
'How would you describe it?' 'Well,
it is really a mixture of not knowing what

1262.30.text:
you're doing and not knowing what you're
doing,' but there you go. I just read every

1266.19.text:
account I possibly could. I read all the newspapers
of the period. I read people's journals.

1270.07.text:
I read all the political papers, and I tried
to draw up a timeline to see what had really

1275.72.text:
happened. I got more and more puzzled, because
Annie Besant never talks about a strike in

1280.15.text:
her article; she talks about a boycott. That
was a typical practice of the time, a middle

1285.14.text:
class boycott of a particularly bad employer's
product, but there is nothing about a strike.

1290.21.text:
Then, in the same issue of her paper, the
link in which White Slavery in London appears,

1294.64.text:
there is an opinion piece by Annie Besant,
saying, 'About this trade union business

1299.98.text:
-- now, people are saying that these casual
workers and women as well should be organised

1304.69.text:
into trade unions. Well, what a stupid idea.
That would never work. As soon as they went

1309.56.text:
on strike they would be sacked, they would
be out of a job and they would be replaced',

1312.85.text:
because you have a huge pool of unemployed
in London, and East London, in this period.

1318.22.text:
You can see her point, for practical reasons,
but that does not sound like the way a strike

1322.08.text:
leader would talk, unless she is being incredibly
cunning and hiding her plan of action.

1329.11.text:
I also looked in the Bryant and May archives,
and, fortunately, they had all been given

1333.72.text:
to a library in Hackney. I also found a list
the foreman had drawn up of five women they

1342.48.text:
thought were really behind the strike, Bryant
and May's naughty list of reprobates and

1347.47.text:
trouble makers. Obviously, if the strike was,
in the opinion of the foreman, organised from

1353.43.text:
inside the workplace, it could not have been
triggered and orchestrated from the outside

1357.38.text:
as well. It just does not make sense. So it
took me a good while, about 10 years, on and

1362.75.text:
off -- I was incredibly young when I started;
I know you are thinking that -- but, by slowly

1367.39.text:
piecing together every account I could find
of the strike, I drew up a new timeline. I

1372.35.text:
also traced descendants of some of the original
matchwomen, and that was by far the most exciting

1376.93.text:
piece of my work: to meet people who had actually
known these women as their grandmothers was

1381.59.text:
amazing, and it is such a shame that Ted Lewis
could not be here today.

1385.42.text:
What happened, I think, was this. Bryant and
May read Annie Besant's article at the

1390.93.text:
end of June 1888. She made sure they did.
She telegraphed them to tell them, 'You

1395.09.text:
might want to buy my paper, and you might
want to see an article. It might be of some

1398.09.text:
interest to you.' Bryant and May were absolutely
furious, and they started to bully the workers

1405.06.text:
almost immediately. They put papers around
every workroom that the women were supposed

1409.57.text:
to sign underneath, saying, 'We absolutely
love working for Bryant and May. We couldn't

1414.14.text:
be happier. They're the most marvellous
employers, and this Annie Besant, every word

1418.44.text:
she's written is a lie', but they wouldn't
do it. Now, that was incredibly brave, because

1424.05.text:
they knew they risked the sack, and they needed
their wages desperately, but every single

1428.24.text:
woman refused to sign, they even delivered
a handwritten note to Annie Besant's house,

1433.42.text:
and this is one of the few examples of what
we know to be the matchwomen's own words. Here

1438.22.text:
is what they said: 'Dear Lady. They've
been trying to get the poor girls to say it

1443.64.text:
is all lies that has been written, and to
sign a paper. We will not sign. We hope you

1449.59.text:
will not get into any trouble on our behalf,
as you have stood up for us, and what you

1454.15.text:
have spoken is quite true.' I always find
that so touching, that the matchwomen were

1458.34.text:
concerned about Annie Besant. 'You know,
she stuck up for us, fair enough. We're

1461.35.text:
not having anybody saying she's lying.'
Annie Besant could look after herself, but,

1468.69.text:
Bryant and May next made an example of one
girl, who they believed was a ringleader of

1473.80.text:
the strike. All we know about her from the
press of the time was she was pale little

1477.15.text:
person in black who was popular with her workmates.
She was sacked on an excuse. All the other

1483.26.text:
workers knew why she had really been sacked,
and they all streamed out of the gates of

1487.02.text:
that factory on the Bow Road behind her. Instead
of doing what the middle classes and the media

1493.47.text:
at the time might have expected of working
class people who had walked out of work -- go

1497.41.text:
down the pub or the music hall, or just wander
off home confusedly -- they got tactical

1502.47.text:
almost immediately. They assembled a picket
line at the gates, and they also elected,

1507.07.text:
in a very democratic way, six women to go
back inside and put their terms to Bryant

1512.98.text:
and May. I think that those six women are
among the women in this picture, and that

1517.63.text:
is why these are the ones that have photographed
here. This is right outside the factory gates

1522.43.text:
of Bryant and May. Bryant and May hear their
terms, which include the reinstatement of

1530.21.text:
the sacked girl, an end to the fines and a
proper dining room away from the phosphorus

1534.96.text:
fumes, because they knew very well what was
causing phossy jaw. Bryant and May responded

1539.74.text:
by threatening the strikers with dismissal
en masse unless they went back immediately,

1544.00.text: but they would not go back.

1547.43.text:
1,400 women and some men and boys as well
are demonstrating around the streets of Bow,

1554.11.text:
singing, I'm afraid to have to tell you,
some rather rude songs about their employers,

1557.71.text:
because there is a lovely little bit of oral
history in the British Library about this

1561.24.text:
song they sung, which I am far too polite
to repeat to you now. The only person who

1567.14.text:
is nowhere to be seen is our Annie Besant.
She is not on the scene, and she would have

1570.88.text:
been mentioned in the local papers, because
she was quite the celebrity socialist; she

1574.21.text:
was very well known at the time. I found out
why, eventually, from her own journal. She

1580.82.text:
said she was working in her offices in Fleet
Street, and there was a bit of a ruckus down

1583.85.text:
below. She looked out of the window and there
were all these women, a raggedy band of women,

1590.85.text:
downstairs. Her concern was that she did not
know who they were or why they were there,

1594.50.text:
but they were blocking the pavement, and respectable
people wanted to get past. She sent down a

1599.63.text:
note asking would they please move and who
were they? She then saw three of the women;

1604.54.text:
she had them up to tea, and she said they
were really quite respectable. She asked them

1608.39.text:
why they had come. They told her they were
on strike.

1612.42.text:
Now, that is a very sloppy strike leader who
does not even know that a strike has begun.

1616.67.text:
She was not even monitoring events at the
factory, let alone directing them. She never

1621.74.text:
claims otherwise; this is not a Besant bashing
exercise at all. She did not want the title

1628.44.text:
of 'strike leader'; she actively rejected
it. She wrote letters to The Times around

1632.71.text:
this period; she gave the strike excellent
publicity, but she constantly says, 'It

1636.96.text:
is absolutely false to say that I started
the strike. I was nowhere near the factory

1640.94.text:
when it began. It wasn't me, guv', basically,
and she says this over and over again.

1647.11.text:
She also says that she thinks striking is
a mistake. She says, in her next issue of

1650.93.text:
the paper, 'the girls will go back to work'.
Actually, the girls would not go back to work,

1654.89.text:
and did not, but she was really keen. You
can understand that, because 1,400 desperately

1660.63.text:
poor women on the streets of the East End
with no financial means of support from a

1665.72.text:
practical point of view, yes, is worrying,
but she certainly was not celebrating the

1669.49.text: fact they had gone on strike.

1671.15.text:
This begins to really attract a lot of press
attention. It is in the East End, near enough

1677.38.text:
to the houses of Parliament to cause trouble,
and at a time when people thought social revolution

1682.27.text:
was a real possibility, so it starts picking
up a lot of press attention, and it starts

1686.80.text:
to be called 'the match girls' strike'.
The women went several days without work,

1691.83.text:
but the journalists were quite surprised,
because a lot of journalists would probably

1694.53.text:
not have met working class women -- not this
working class, anyway. They were quite surprised

1699.07.text:
and curious. They were saying, 'This is
extraordinary. You should see the clothes

1703.03.text:
they wear. They wear these skirts with patches
on, as if it was a fashion, and their boots

1708.74.text:
really need a polish.' Well, yes -- they
are poor. They were quite amazed to find them

1713.72.text:
sticking up for each other, because the image
of the poor is completely mindless, completely

1718.75.text:
selfish, just out for themselves, no political
intelligence whatsoever, and they say, 'No,

1723.77.text:
it's not true. You can hear them saying
to each other, "Well, I can pawn that for

1727.08.text:
you" or "I can lend you that" or "We
can give you a meal" and all helping each

1730.66.text:
other on while they try to raise funds for
the strike.'

1738.96.text:
The East End working class were so cut off
from London that, at this point, when the

1743.04.text:
matchwomen do march to Parliament -- not
on Parliament, I have to say, but to Parliament,

1746.97.text:
because there is quite a difference -- it
causes absolute uproar; it literally stops

1752.39.text:
the traffic. The sight of poor working class
women in posh bits of London is absolutely

1757.16.text:
shocking. They get catcalls, apparently, and
quite a lot of abuse from passers by, but

1761.17.text:
they hold their heads high, and they impress
the MPs they meet with to talk about their

1766.26.text:
lives, and I think surprise them as well a
bit by their eloquence and the honest stories

1771.93.text:
they tell about the difficulties of their
lives. It is really because of that that political

1779.26.text:
pressure begins to grow on Bryant and May.
A lot of shareholders are MPs and clergymen,

1784.72.text:
and it all gets a bit embarrassing when, in
their day jobs, they are defending the poor,

1788.91.text:
and then they are being exposed as having
these shares and being paid these massive

1794.07.text:
So Bryant and May are eventually forced into
a climb down, incredibly reluctantly. They

1800.64.text:
did not take it well, it has to be said. It
was not done with good grace at all. There

1804.40.text:
are letters in their archives years later
saying, 'Don't talk to us about that strike.

1808.45.text:
It was completely unreasonable. There was
no need for it whatsoever' -- really bitter,

1812.22.text:
I have to say. But they had to concede. They
had no choice; their share price was tumbling,

1817.71.text:
and, in two weeks, these women, unorganised
with no trade union, had won better rates

1822.91.text:
of pay, an end to those fines, a separate
dining room and the right to form what became

1828.98.text:
the largest union of women and girls in the
country at the time.

1832.87.text:
It is a remarkable victory, but it is more
remarkable, I think, that historians have

1838.32.text:
continued to portray them, even after that,
as this helpless bunch of girlies who really

1843.65.text:
did not know what they were doing, and thank
goodness Annie Besant was there to tell them

1847.48.text:
what to do and show them the way. A year later,
there was a huge dock strike in the same part

1852.46.text:
of London, and that has always been considered
incredibly important. It is rather interesting

1856.23.text:
how the fact that the matchwomen's strike
happened a year before gets explained away:

1861.88.text:
'Well, it was sort of before, but it just
a sign of what was coming. It didn't influence

1867.72.text:
anybody at all. It couldn't have influenced
anybody, because they were women, and the

1870.68.text:
dockers were men.' Literally -- I am not
really exaggerating very much there. I was

1876.15.text:
really quite surprised when I starting looking
at the research, or the lack of research,

1880.97.text: into the connection between the two strikes.

1883.07.text:
Through several years of research, I had the
pleasure of making the acquaintance of the

1888.51.text:
matchwomen, through the pages of history,
and I found that they were not ignorant factory

1893.22.text:
girls, not slum lasses or helpless waifs,
and certainly no one's poor little match

1898.29.text:
girls; that is for sure. This picture features
the same women as the first picture we have

1902.81.text:
just been looking at, but you would not really
know it. They are a lot more glammed up here,

1906.47.text:
and they look like very different women. They
are far more confident. This is actually their

1910.51.text:
strike committee. It is Annie Besant in the
pale dress at the lectern, and next to her

1915.45.text:
-- because people ask me -- it is not a
very butch matchwomen; it is Herbert Burrows

1918.75.text:
of the Fabian Society. That is the guy with
the moustache. Everyone else is female. This

1926.00.text:
was much later in the strike. You can see
their confidence increasing. In the first picture,

1930.55.text:
they have just walked out on strike. They
do not know what they are going to do. They

1933.63.text:
are tired; they have been up since five in
the morning, and they are quite worried about

1936.54.text:
what the future holds, but here, 'Hey, you
know, we've been in the papers, we've

1940.64.text:
met with MPs and we're really doing rather
well.' You can see the confidence.

1944.67.text:
They would also have got their best dresses
probably out of the pawn shop, because you

1948.11.text:
would have to pawn your best stuff when your
wages ran out, and then get them out again

1952.09.text:
when you got paid; they have had their hair
done, and they really look rather glam, don't

1957.65.text:
they? These were the matchwomen that were
known and not, I'm afraid, really approved

1961.91.text:
of by the middle classes. It was said that,
before the strike, they were well known. You

1967.49.text:
could spot at matchwomen by the freedom of
her walk, the number of her friends, and the

1971.56.text:
shrillness of her laugh -- tut, tut. You
would also notice her bright clothes. If she

1977.00.text:
was not heard -- and she generally would
be heard -- she could be seen. They favoured

1981.85.text:
really bright clothes, which was not how the
poor were supposed to dress -- I mean, a

1987.35.text:
bit of beige, for goodness's sake. No: bright
clothes, fringe hairstyles, little high heeled

1991.02.text:
boots and hats; they loved their hats, did
the matchwomen. Because they couldn't afford

1996.74.text:
to buy their own on their wages, they paid
into what they called 'feather clubs'.

2000.14.text:
They had communal hat buying clubs, and they
contributed a penny a week of whatever they

2004.58.text:
could afford. When they had enough, Elsie
would go down and buy a hat from the milliners,

2009.17.text:
but, again, would she go for a nice, modest
little bonnet? No, I'm afraid not: the biggest

2013.90.text:
hats they could possibly get, with the brightest
and the biggest feathers. It really wouldn't

2021.27.text:
One popular resident -- I found a lovely
bit of history when I was looking through

2024.57.text:
someone's archives -- remembered not just
the hats, but the hatpins. Big hat, big hatpin

2030.12.text:
-- it sounds a bit like a euphemism, but
it isn't. He said, 'These match girls

2033.49.text:
were very tough, you know. On rare occasions
when in any trouble, they didn't hesitate

2038.07.text:
to use these horrible long hatpins to defend
themselves,' so dressed to kill, very literally.

2045.51.text:
I found, when I was really late into my research,
a really interesting bit in the daily news

2050.25.text:
that suggested that the matchwomen might have
even upset Jack the Ripper, which is quite

2055.81.text:
impressive. 'Intimation was given to the
city police on Saturday morning that Messrs

2059.81.text:
Bryant and May received a letter from a person
signing himself J Ripper couched in the following

2065.29.text:
terms: "I hereby notify that I'm going
to pay your girls a visit. I hear they're

2071.87.text:
beginning to say what they would do with me.
I'm going to see what a few of them have

2075.88.text:
in their stomachs"' -- how delightful
-- '"and I will take it out of them.

2079.71.text:
Signed John Ripper"' -- not Jack, but
John. It is probably a hoax, but what is so

2084.95.text:
interesting about it is that the chap is saying,
'These matchwomen are going around like

2089.68.text:
vigilantes'. They are not scared, like most
people quite understandably were; at this

2094.20.text:
time, five women had been murdered in the
East End, but they are not terrified. They

2098.97.text:
are saying, 'Wait 'til we get our hands
on that' expletive deleted. They are threatening

2105.29.text:
the Ripper himself. There was probably an
element of bravado; there cannot have been

2109.84.text:
many women hoping to bump into Jack the Ripper
down a back alley at this point. No matchwoman

2114.13.text:
ever did fall victim to Jack the Ripper as
far as we know, but I do think it is a shame

2118.14.text:
that a gang of them with their hatpins at
the ready did not come across him one night

2124.71.text:
The local magistrate that I mentioned earlier
said that, 'When they came back from nights

2128.65.text:
out, you always knew it was the matchwomen,
because you could hear choruses of all the

2133.38.text:
music hall songs of the day shattering the
peace of the night.' 'Ta-ra-ra Boom-de-ay'

2138.87.text:
and 'Knocked Em in the Old Kent Road'
were their favourites, apparently. 'They

2142.14.text:
seem to know by heart the words of all the
popular music hall songs of the day', he

2147.32.text:
said, sounding rather tired as he writes.
Another commentator said, 'These matchwomen

2152.04.text:
are insolent. They have insolent confidence,
but also they are very loyal to each other.

2157.05.text:
When a girl is out of work they stick together'.
That was really key.

2161.90.text:
Connections with the dockers were everywhere
as well. Even before I interviewed descendants

2167.19.text:
of match girls' families, I found from the
census that matchwomen and dockers were not,

2171.68.text:
as some historians have said, completely separate
groups. They were in the same streets, in

2177.05.text:
the same houses, in the same families. You
cannot get much closer than that. In fact,

2181.42.text:
one commentator said, 'Match girls and dockers
tend to marry each other. They tend to date

2185.41.text:
each other.' Well, they would. They are
both an Irish community, and they are both

2189.61.text:
casual labourers in the East End in this period.
It would be really surprising if the one victory

2194.42.text:
had not influenced the other strike.
When the dockers went on strike, I found that

2200.33.text:
the matchwomen struck as well -- secondary
action: you cannot do that anymore can you?

2205.02.text:
-- and, during the victory procession of
the dock strike, the Star newspaper gives

2209.86.text:
us a glimpse of some familiar faces. They
said, 'Up came the dockers, then a large

2214.41.text:
contingent of women, matchmakers among others,
advancing like a moving rainbow. They all

2220.62.text:
wear the huge hats of feathers of many colours
they love to sport when on a day out.' I

2225.31.text:
do love the idea of a strike demonstration
as a bit of a day out -- get your best hat

2229.84.text: on for it, and why not?

2232.24.text:
They also went on to recruit other working
women, and their recruitment meetings were

2236.32.text:
a bit of a party, really. There was a lot
of tea and cakes going down; a bit of Irish

2239.38.text:
dancing, and why not? That was the spirit
that I really looked at when I was organising

2244.11.text:
the festival last year to celebrate the 125th
anniversary of the strike. It was a bit of

2249.63.text:
a knees-up, I am glad to say, and we did have
Irish music, and tea and cake, and beer curry.

2255.16.text:
I was delighted that 700 people came, including
the late lamented Bob Crow. I was also pleased

2260.71.text:
to introduce -- let's embarrass her again
-- Frances O'Grady, the first female General

2266.22.text:
Secretary of the TUC, and also from a good
Irish family, and proof that you just can't

2273.67.text:
So the matchwomen were incredible. They completely
confounded the judgment of their betters.

2279.11.text:
They broke every convention of respectable
Victorian female behaviour. They changed history

2285.04.text:
forever for working people. Without them,
we would not have had the workers' rights

2289.24.text:
we have today, but the rights that we are
also fighting so desperately to maintain.

2294.55.text:
It is a fight; the press does like to talk
about health and safety gone mad, but do not

2299.51.text:
be fooled by that. Because of the scrapping
of regulations and enforcement, workers in

2303.60.text:
the public are at greater risk now than they
have been for decades from industrial accidents.

2309.66.text:
In this country, almost the entire strike
force of Bryant and May, which was 1,400 women,

2315.23.text:
is killed every year at work: 1,300 men and
women die every year at work, but you may

2320.97.text:
well not read about it in the papers. Frank
was talking about the debate in Parliament

2326.60.text:
last October. On 8 October, a young building
worker died in East London, Daniel Yeowell,

2332.68.text:
who was working on a building site at a primary
school. We should not forget him and those

2338.20.text:
like him, and we should not forget the spirit
of the matchwomen and what they were fighting

2342.02.text:
for. They were not just stroppy Irish girls
-- but there is nothing wrong with that.

2346.01.text:
They changed the world for the better, when
it really needed to be changed, and they would

2350.82.text:
be livid if they thought all of that had been
for nothing, and I think I have proved you

2355.77.text:
do not want to upset a matchwomen, so let's
remember.
